Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2010 08:25AM samiam wrote: After my BMX and reconstruction, I had an infection on one side that we could not clear with ABX. It manifested itself with redness, warmth, and a slight fever.   I had to have the TE removed and waited 7 months for healing for a replacement.  The Alloderm was infected and had to be removed as well.  We have no idea if the Alloderm was a cause for the infection or if it just became infected along with my skin and TE. I had a second infection scare at replacement time, but this time the heavy duty antibiotics cleared it. We used IV antibiotics for 6 weeks plus an oral one.    We are not sure there was really any infection that time, but no one was taking any chances. I had my exchange and nipple surgery in January and all is going well. There is light at the end of the tunnel! Do you have the redness and imflammation on both sides or just one?  Most people who have an "infection" seem to have it on one side.  If it is both, I might suspect some sort of imflammatory reaction. There are a couple of threads under the Breast Reconstruction Forum (Look for Infection in the thread titles) that are discussing this topic also.  Unfortunately this is more common than we would like.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Has anyone had a reaction to alloderm? chris14 chris14

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 12:13PM samiam wrote: I had surgery at 2:00 on Friday afternoon (bilateral with reconstruction).  I was able to leave after 2 nights at 11:00 a.m. on Sunday.  The two nights were a blessing as I had someone to change dressings, empty drains, and administer medications.  I only had a 5 mile trip home on Sunday and managed that very well.
Posts.Title: How Long in Hospital after Bi-Later with Reconstruction? Mocity mom_of_2

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 09:32PM samiam wrote: It is wonderful to hear all the positive stories from women with lymph node positive BC.  I (much to the surprise of myself and my physicians) was diagnosed with IDC and one positive node.  I had a tumor less than 1 cm, grade 1, very low KI-67 ... and guess what?  I still had a positive node.  It has been one year since I finished chemo and I'm doing great. Now if I could only figre out how to manage this curly hair!
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2008 11:10AM samiam wrote: I had a very small, low grade, lesion and was shocked (along with my surgeons) to find I had a positive lymph node.  Chemo is generally always recommended if a positive node is found.  I looked for every excuse in the world to avoid it and dreaded it more than my mastectomy and reconstruction surgeries.  I finally decided to suck it up and  go for it. It turned out to not be nearly as terrible as I thought.  Chemo is doable. Even the ladies who had much tougher side effects that I, generally say this.  I wish you the best.
Posts.Title: do i have to have chemo?? lovemyfamilysomuch lovemyfamilysomuch

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 05:09PM samiam wrote: This is all very interesting to me.  I am getting conflicting information as to whether I had micromets or a full-up macrometastisis in my lymph node. Everything I read states 2mm as the cutoff.  My path report stated that I had 3 small foci 1.2mm, .5mm, and .8mm of cancer in 1 of 6 nodes.  Is it micromets because no cancer deposit was greater than 2mm ... or is it macro because in aggregate they total 2.5mm? I asked on the John Hopkins message board and I was told micromets.  My path report show N1 however instead of the NImi .
Posts.Title: what is the latest on micromets? minxie minxie

Posts.Content: samiam wrote: I am day 12 of TX 3 of taxotere and cytoxin and have swelling and soreness in my recontstructed breasts.  (One is swollen more than the other.)  When I look back, at about this time during TXs 1 and 2 I had issues with my exanders as well. I'm 8 weeks out of surgery and   I have completed all of may fills. Does it make sense that  because this tissue is still healing (skin/alloderm/muscles) that I have stronger side effects here than with other parts of my body?  I've run in to my PS on previous treatments just sure I had a raging infection with my expanders! The first time he assured me everythig was fine.  The second time, I had redness at the incision site and he gave me a course of antibiotices.  Both times the swelling/redness cleared up the next week.  Has anyone else experienced anthing like this with chemo and reconstruction? Maybe I do have a lingering infection and it kicks in during the time that my WBC is lowest?    Dx 7/1/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 1, 1/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and effects on reconstruction samiam samiam

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 07:04PM - edited Nov 7, 2008 07:06PM by samiam I chose a bilateral mastectomy for multiple reasons. I know we're all different but in my case, it was the "right thing". Like encoremom,  I wanted to minimize the risk of recurrance.  Other random reasons included:  1.) I wanted to avoid radiation 2.) I chose expander/implant reconstruction. If I had had radiation and required a mastectomy at a later time, the reconstruction would have been difficult on the radiated breast.  3.) I never wanted to have another mammogram!  4.) My BS told me that with a lumpectomy, he'd go back in once for a clean margin if necessary; but would do a mastectomy if a clean margin was not obtained on round 2.  I didn't want to start with a lumpectomy only to end up with a mastectomy anyway. 5.) The location of my lump was also a factor.  It was just behind and below the aereola and would likely leave a dent. 6.)Finally,  I never liked my real breasts anyway! :) As others have mentioned, it is right for everyone.  For me it was.
Posts.Title: For those who "could" have Lumpectomy.... why choose Mast? Estepp sbmolee

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 05:31PM samiam wrote: Thanks Tender.  I'm going to really push for Oncotype testing (if only to help determine "Which" chemotherapy is best).  I'll read up on invitro cell testing.
Posts.Title: Anyone node positive choose not to do chemo? samiam samiam

Posts.Content: samiam wrote: I have a 9mm lesion IDC, strongly ER/PR positive, Her2 negative, Grade 1, with a low KI-67 score. I was destined for hormonal treatment only. A few days after bilateral mastectomy (with lymph nodes showing clear) I received the final path report. Micrometastis <2mm was detected in a sentinal node. Has anyone with similar stats decided against chemotherapy? Adjuvant Online shows only a 3-4% benefit in overall survival with chemo. Based on answers to other questions and a lot of reading of the threads, I understand most opt for chemo in this situation. I don't believe I am eligible for Oncotype testing as I'm pre-menopausal with a positive node. I don't mind doing chemo for a reasonable benefit; I'm just not sure a 3-4% absolute benefit is worth it! Dx 7/1/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 1, 1/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone node positive choose not to do chemo? samiam samiam
